title: Korean-Style Tteok
subtitle: with Spicy Pork "Ragù" & Gai Lan
time: Tteok are a class of steamed Korean rice cake that can be prepared in countless ways. There are elaborate versions traditionally served at celebrations, and simple preparations that are considered comfort foods. Dressed up or down, tteok are delicious. In our version, we were inspired by their unique texture. We’re using them just like pasta: boiling them until tender and serving them with a Korean-style “ragù” and seasonal vegetables.
desc: Tteok are a class of steamed Korean rice cake that can be prepared in countless ways. There are elaborate versions traditionally served at celebrations, and simple preparations that are considered comfort foods. Dressed up or down, tteok are delicious. In our version, we were inspired by their unique texture. We’re using them just like pasta: boiling them until tender and serving them with a Korean-style “ragù” and seasonal vegetables.

steps.title: Prepare the ingredients:
steps.desc: Wash and dry the fresh produce. Heat a medium pot of salted water to boiling on high. Remove the very end of the gai lan stems; roughly chop the gai lan leaves and stems. Peel and mince the garlic and ginger. Remove and discard the root end of the scallions; thinly slice the scallions, separating the white bottoms and green tops. Peel and small dice the onion.

steps.title: Cook the pork:
steps.desc: In a large pan (nonstick if you have one), heat 2 teaspoons of oil on medium until hot. Add the pork and season with salt and pepper. Cook, frequently breaking the meat apart with a spoon, 4 to 6 minutes, or until browned and cooked through. Transfer to a bowl and set aside, leaving any drippings in the pan.

steps.title: Cook the aromatics:
steps.desc: Heat the pan of reserved pork drippings on medium until hot. Add the garlic, ginger, onion and white bottoms of the scallions. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until fragrant and the onion has softened.

steps.title: Make the "ragù":
steps.desc: To the pan of aromatics, add the gai lan, sweet soy sauce, garlic black bean sauce, heavy cream, cooked pork, ½ cup of water and as much of the gochujang as you’d like, depending on how spicy you’d like the dish to be. Cook, stirring occasionally, 7 to 9 minutes, or until the sauce has thickened.

steps.title: Cook the rice cakes & add them to the "ragù":
steps.desc: After the sauce has cooked for 5 minutes, add the Korean rice cakes to the pot of boiling water. Cook 2 to 3 minutes. Drain and immediately transfer to the pan of ragù; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until the Korean rice cakes are thoroughly coated in the sauce. Remove from heat and season with salt and pepper to taste.

steps.title: Finish & plate your dish:
steps.desc: Divide the Korean rice cakes and “ragù” between 2 dishes. Garnish with the green tops of the scallions. Enjoy!
